headline.main: Seeking Freedom and Security at a Time of War

lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Civil Liberty vs. Security: Finding a Wartime Balance'' (front page, Nov. 18): The surest test of a fair system is whether we would mind having it applied to ourselves if the tables were turned. When President Bush makes rules for the surveillance and prosecution of resident foreigners, he needs to make them as if they applied to Americans living abroad, who not infrequently find themselves in trouble with local law. When he establishes a tribunal for war criminals, he needs to establish one that we would be happy to live with if it were applied to American pilots downed over foreign airspace or American travelers charged with espionage.
abstract: James C Raymond letter, commenting on Nov 18 article, says US should not use procedures for trying alleged terrorists that it would not want Americans living abroad to face in similar circumstances
